data.text: Index
Appendix 1 - Organisational Structure
Appendix 2 - Glossary of Terms
Appendix 3 - Elective Flows into the Diabetic Service Appendix 4 - Type 1 Diabetes Mellitus Patient Pathway Appendix 5 - Type 2 Pathway
Appendix 6 - Summary of Diabetes Service Components
Purpose
To describe in detail the Diabetes Service provided by Mid Essex Hospital NHS Trust in  primary and secondary care in partnership with Provide.
To evidence the key working relationships between within the members of the diabetes multidisciplinary team (MDT) which enables both prompt clinical discussion and joint clinical decision making.
Aims of the Service
To meet the complex needs of patients living with diabetes through a range of services outlined later in this document.
To provide a highly specialist Diabetes Service, based on clinical excellence and evidenced based care across both Primary and Secondary care settings.
To deliver a multi-professional model of care via a ‘one-stop shop' approach where appropriate.
To empower patients to self –manage their diabetes via provision of in- depth education programs, aiming to reduce or delay the development of long term complication of diabetes.
To ensure a high standard of diabetes care delivery, via provision and support of education at pre-registration and post- graduate levels for multiple occupational groups.
To be the Diabetes Service of ‘choice,' for the people of Mid Essex and the wider community.
To lead on the development of new services and technologies e.g. insulin pumps and continuous blood glucose monitoring
To deliver a Diabetes Service that is compliant with:
The National Service Framework for Diabetes
NICE: National Institute of Clinical Excellence Guidelines for Diabetes.
Diabetes UK
National Diabetes Support Team
CCG Long term conditions strategy
JBDS guidelines
Scope of the Service

This comprehensive service reaches across both the primary and secondary care settings, providing highly specialist care for patients with Type 1, Type 2 and Gestational diabetes. (Refer to appendix 1). The service operates between Monday and Friday with on call provision for monitoring known urgent newly diagnosed patients or Insulin Pump Therapy naive patients.
3.2.  Inclusion Criteria
This service provides care for patients with Type 1, Type 2, and gestational diabetes that are  years of age or over.
Exclusion Criteria
3.3.1 The Diabetic Service does not provide care for patients under the age of  year, with the   exception of patents under 16 who are pregnant and requiring specialist intervention.

3.3.2 The Paediatric Service is delivered and managed by the Paediatric team in line with the National Service Framework for Children's Services. The team comprises consultant paediatricians with an interest in Diabetes, Diabetes Specialist Nurses and a dietician. The service has strong links with Phoenix ward and in the community
3.3.3 Adolescent transition clinics are run jointly by the Adult team and Paediatric team.
Inpatient  Care Provision
Service provision for those whose reason for admission is a primary or secondary
diagnosis of Diabetes Mellitus. This service provides specialist MDT care for acute
diagnosis and for the unwell or unstable patient with diabetes. This service is ongoing
throughout the inpatient episode and follow up care is provided in the outpatient setting if
required.
The key objective of the service is to reduce disease related complications. For those   patients requiring admission, a reduced length of stay is paramount. This is achieved by
specialist review and the development of effective and robust clinical management plans
including medication adjustment. These reviews are undertaken frequently during the in-
patient episode by the diabetes specialist nurses and consultants if required. The diabetes
MDT maintains close working relationship with many other specialties e.g. Podiatry,
Vascular, Renal, Cardiology and Ophthalmology.
Daily Diabetes Specialist Nurse (DSN) visits to the Emergency village to prevent admission   where possible and to expedite discharge as appropriate.
Rapid DSN attendance in A&E upon request.
DNS's work in partnership with Clinical Nurse Specialist and PAM's to formulate joint   clinical management plans.
Out-patient care within the Diabetes Centre

For Type 2 diabetic patients with Complex care needs (defined as 2 or more complications associated with diabetes that over-arch more than one specialty) e.g. diabetic nephropathy, neuropathy, retinopathy, cardio vascular complications.
Type 1 patients including adolescent transition from the Paediatric Service.
Diabetes Specialist Nurse led Pre-conceptual care for patients with existing Typeor Type 2 diabetes (see glossary).
Continuing care during pregnancy for patients with Type 1, Type 2 and gestational diabetes, in conjunction with the Obstetric service and Diabetes Specialist Midwife.
Diabetes Specialist midwife led clinics for follow up of some lower risk patients with pre – existing Diabetes or gestational diabetes up until 36 weeks gestation.

The Diabetic Foot Service supports a rapid access foot ulcer service run by the Provide podiatrists within the diabetes centre, with support & advice from the consultant diabetologist team available on request. This service aims to reduce or escalate admission as required. The strategies adopted by this service aim to reduce the risk of lower limb amputation.
Telephone and Email Advisory Service aimed at crisis intervention and Admission Avoidance by DSN team.
Structured group education programs for patients with Type 1 Diabetes new to Insulin pumps (CSII), newly diagnosed Type 1 Group education and Type 2 Insulin conversion group follow up as required
BERTIE Structured education for Type 1 Diabetes
Structured group education for patient with Type 1 diabetes.
Course runs for 4 days over 4 weeks
There 8 courses commissioned per annum
Insulin Pump Service and continuous blood glucose monitoring where required.

Support and clinical advice for other Health Care Professionals, including Professionals Allied to Medicine, Junior Medical Staff, Ward Staff, Local General Practitioners, District Nursing and Community Teams. This service raises the standard for diabetes care delivery via the provision and support of education at pre and post registration levels for multiple occupational groups.

Urgent working day access by General Practitioners for emergency insulin starts for newly diagnosed Type 1 diabetics. This often negates the need for emergency admission into secondary care if treated promptly.
Diabetes Specialist Nurses and Consultants participate in Consultant Connect to enable GPs quick telephone access for urgent advice and support.
Work Flows
Patients enter the diabetic service from both the emergency and elective pathways, please see appendix 2 for detailed work flows.
Key Relationships
The effectiveness of the Diabetes Service is underpinned by the co-location of the

multidisciplinary team and the clinical integration with the community service offered by   Provide. This cohesive approach facilitates a comprehensive assessment for all patients   accessing the service, thus reducing the clinical risk and proving a seamless service for   users and an enhanced patient experience.
The multidisciplinary team consists of :
Consultant Diabetologists
Diabetes Clinical Nurse Specialists (DSN)
Specialist Dieticians
Specialist Podiatrists
Support staff e.g. Health Care Assistant
Administration Staff
Diabetes Specialist Midwife.
Key Relationships with other Departments.
Pathology Department
Radiology Department
Pharmacy
Cardiac Department
Domestic Services
Medical Secretaries
Vascular Lab
Estates and Facilities
Patient Transport Services
ICT & Communication Department
Phlebotomy
Medical Records and Clinical Coding
Emergency Village including Accident and Emergency
All wards within MEHT
Outpatients
Specialist Teams e.g. Obstetrics, Renal, Ophthalmology, Cardiology, Vascular
Commercial services/Office Depot
Chemotherapy Day Unit
Dietetics
Tissue Viability
Other Clinical Nurse Specialist Groups
Key Relationships with External Stakeholders
Clinical Commissioning groups
Provide( Formerly Central Essex Community Services)
Community Teams e.g. District & Practice Nurses
Social Services
Diabetes UK (see glossary of terms)
GPwSIs (GPs with Specialist Interest in Diabetes)
Environmental Requirements
7.5.1 The current diabetes centre comprises:

Dedicated space for multi-disciplinary activity in which all health care professionals work and interact within the same location. This enables the continuation of the “one stop” approach care provision that has been developed and evolved over a number of years based on Best Practice Guidelines and National Tariff.

7.5.2 Accommodation located within Broomfield Hospital site to allow personnel to deal with day to day running issues such as providing ward cover, managing the outreach service, manning the telephone and email advisory service and dealing with general enquires whilst located within the clinic setting:
1 Treatment room, the treatment room houses an electronically operated podiatry couch, work surfaces and storage cupboards for dressings and appliances.
1 seminar room that doubles up as a waiting room during clinics
Reception area that has the waiting capacity for 5 people.
1 large office for the Clinical Nurse Specialists( 3)
4 offices for the Clinical Nurses Specialist team and dietetic team, based on 2 members of staff per office and “hot desking”
2 consulting rooms that facilitate the ‘one stop shop' model of care.
Store Cupboard
Small kitchen area, to allow patients attending the education and disease management sessions the ability to prepare snacks.
NB the areas identified in italics have dual function and act as Nurse/ Dietitian consulting areas when required
Standard requirements
Standard lighting and ventilation for all consultation and non- clinical rooms
Extraction for treatment rooms to manage odours
No carpets in clinical areas or treatment rooms to meet infection control requirements
Wheelchair and disabled access
Standard requirement for heating.
Ability to facilitate the privacy and dignity requirements for those patients attending the department.
Data Security
The service will be delivered in accordance with and compliance to the Trust's IT Policies.
Data sharing agreements will be drawn up to cover all data sharing outside the Trust in accordance with the Trust data sharing policy.

Outside of standard operational hours the department is accessed via swipe card access, as the department holds patient sensitive data. There is an intercom system to allow communication during this time; this maintains safety for staff that are working alone in the evening.
Lockable cupboards are available for the storage of laptops and other expensive items.
All patients medical records will be managed confidentially at all times and stored securely in locked office or outpatient facility whilst not in use.
All movement of patient records will be accurately tracked in accordance with the Trust's Case note Tracking Policy.
Security for Patients
The service will be delivered in accordance with and compliance to the Trust's Patient Safety Policies.
Security for Staff
The service will be delivered in accordance with and compliance to the Trust's Lone Worker and Security/Risk Management Policies..
The Diabetes Centre is open during operational hours and patients access the area via a manned reception desk.
Manual Handling
The service will be delivered in accordance with and compliance to the Trust's Manual Handing Policies.
ICT Requirements
The service requires access to all standard IT systems e.g. Lorenzo, Vitalpac, PACS, Pathology Results/ Ordering, E mail, Trust intranet/ internet
The service requires desk top computers in all clinical and non – clinical rooms to enable access to the Diabetes clinical management system, DIAMOND ( enabling data entry at the patient interface)
Reception requires the full range of IT services as described above
Fax machine
Printers with high volume capacity
Telephones in all rooms
Diabetes shared drive access for all staff within the service
CGMS and blood glucose meter upload software installation
Encrypted Memory Sticks
Speech Exec
Staffing Profile
Diabetes Centre team (employed by MEHT)

table_items.text: 3.0 (not full time in diabetes, 3 general medicine and endocrine clinics & 8 diabetes clinics, including community out-reach per week plus MDT diabetes work)
Diabetes Specialist Nurses in MEHT (includes service manager)
SLA ( 2 podiatrists and 1 assistant provide 4 clinics per week)

data.text: Community Diabetes team (employed by Provide)
Work patterns
All MDT staff have specific areas of specialist interest; however they are trained to work across all clinical settings and provide cross cover for annual leave, sickness and other absences.

Staff rotas ensure that there is a minimum of 2 Diabetic Nurse Specialists on duty at any one time to provide a basic level of service on the wards / telephone and consultant led clinics. There is dietician cover within the working week (unless exceptional circumstances).
There is a minimum of one Consultant available for discussion on a daily basis.
The diabetes service is delivered within office hours (0900-1700hrs) although some work takes place on some bank holidays to provide ward cover.

The pump service is covered with 24hours a day for the first 7 days, thereafter pump patients utilize the telephone advisory service. The 24 hour service is provided by the Diabetic Nurse Specialist Team.
There must be minimum of one member of the reception staff Monday to Thursday
Insulin
The HCA covers all clinics with the exception of annual leave, DSNs are required to provide this cover in her absence
Training and Education
All team members attend the Trusts annual mandatory training program
New staff member are obliged to attend the Trust induction programs
All MDT staff have had specialist training in diabetes, enabling them to provide expert individualised care, delivered in line with NICE clinical guidelines and NSF for Diabetes
All DSNs will be expected to work within the “Integrated career and competency framework for diabetes nursing” which links with the NHS Skills for Health standard statements
Band 6 DSNs will be expected to attain Level 3 within the competency framework
Band 7 DSNs will be expected to attain Level 4 within the competency framework
Dietitian and podiatrists are bound by similar regulation

All staff will have the opportunity via appraisal to develop in line with service and personal objectives and will be given the opportunity to attend diabetes events and conferences as agreed in appraisal in line with personal development plans
All team members will be compliant with the NHSLA requirements for their clinical area
Facilities

A small kitchen is provided within the Diabetes Centre. This provides a hot water machine, fridge and microwave. This is required as patients on education programs are required to bring in meals for carbohydrate counting practice). Whole day courses are provided with refreshments
Patient toilet facilities are provided, including a disabled toilet
All staff and patients have access to the retail facilities on the Hospital Site
Equipment Requirements
Visual acuity testing charts and space
Standards Weighing scales
Weighing scales with capacity to measure body water and fat %
Height charts and boards
Urine and blood testing equipment
Blood pressure machines
Blood glucose and Ketone meters
Flip charts, data projector, overhead projector and projection screen
Folding tables
Microwave and wall mounted water boiler
Plumbed in cold water machine for patient drinking water
Food models
Specialist podiatry foot-ware
Tuning forks, ophthalmoscopes, monofilaments
Insulin pumps, delivery devices, CGM device
Equality and Diversity

Mid Essex Hospital Services NHS Trust is committed to commit to the provision of a service that is fair, accessible and meets the needs of all individuals. The Diabetic Centre provides access for disabled users.
Contingency
Staffing Issues

In the event of short notice absence due to sickness or carers leave, the nursing staff will provide cross cover to ensure that the service is not unduly affected. In the event of a more prolonged absence guidance would be sought from the service manager and the Associate Director of Nursing for Medicine (ADN) to a more sustainable solution (see Business continuity plan).
In the event of Consultant absence, work that cannot be undertaken by other members of the MDT will be rescheduled in line with the  week targets.
IT Failure

If the ‘Diamond' Clinical Management System fails, all clinicians will revert to standard medical records and a paper record of the episode is maintained until electronic data entry is restored (see Diamond Business Continuity plan).
If pathology review fails, urgent results are obtained via the phone.
Major incident alert

During a Major Incident, re-deployment of some of the Diabetes Specialist Nurses and /or consultants may be required. This would result in the cessation of other clinic activity and in- patient work. Consequently, re-scheduling of this work would be required and in- patient length of stay would be adversely affected. There may be difficulty with 18week compliance in this situation.
Auditing and Monitoring

Discussion of complaints, serious incidents, mortality and Datix reports will take place at the weekly team meeting for action and shared learning. The first Tuesday in the month is a formal timed meeting with an action log. Other audits include :
BERTIE Education program audit (ongoing)
Insulin pump service outcomes
Participation in the National In- patient Audit
Activity in relation to capacity
Compliance with the NSF and NICE guidance (annual)
Blood glucose meter audit led by biochemistry, supported by the Diabetes Team

The Clinical Nurse Manager/ Lead CNS (Clinical Nurse Specialist) and Consultant Team will lead in change and operational developments in conjunction with the Trusts strategic vision and within the context of the Sustainability, Transformation and Productivity agenda ( Mid & South Essex STP).
Mandatory audit such as patient satisfaction is maintained and used to inform service improvement. Use of the Trust wide Friends and family test is encouraged.
Responsibilities
Management structure (Refer to Appendix 1) The service is led by Dr Alan Jackson (Consultant Diabetologist) supported by Dr Jeremy Fletcher and Dr Nisha Kaimal (Consultant Diabetologists)
The day to day operational responsibility lies with the Lead DSN/ Clinical Nurse Manager
The budget is held by the Clinical Nurse Manager/ Lead DSN
The strategic planning for the service is a joint venture between the Consultants and the Clinical Nurse Manager /Lead DSN and is keeping with the wider Trust objectives
Reporting is via the ADN for Medicine
References
The National Service Framework for Diabetes; http://www.dh.gov.uk/en/Publicationsandstatistics/Publications/Publications PolicyAndGuidance/DH_4002951
National Institute for Clinical Excellence http://www.nice.org.uk/;
Best Practice Guidelines www.health.qld.gov.au/diabetes…/diabetes/best_practice_management.html –
Diabetes UK www.diabetes.org.uk
(Joint British Diabetes Societies guidance for in- patient care)

Appendix
Appendix
Glossary of Terms

table_items.text: Admin. and clerical staff who provide support for the smooth running of the service, including telephone triage and provision of reception for the diabetes centre
BERTIE ( Broomfield Education Resource Training for Insulin and Eating)
NICE compliant structured group education for patients with Type 1 diabetes
A system for classification of Chronic Kidney disease
Patients to present to the service with untreated or undetected end stage renal failure that requires emergency renal replacement therapy (RRT) in the form of dialysis rather than planned RRT.
A consultant physician with specialist diabetes knowledge & skills and a proven academic & research background in diabetes

A device fitted by a trained health care professional and worn by a patient (e.g. for 5- 6 days) to enable continual monitoring of blood glucose levels. This enable changes to clinical management plans that simple finger prick testing cannot provide.
A registered nurse with recognised formal specialist training in diabetes. Minimum academic achievement of first level degree and masters level encouraged.
A national charity providing help and support for people living with diabetes. It also supports health care professionals via diabetes research and professional development
A registered dietician with recognised formal specialist training in diabetes. Minimum academic standard of first degree and masters level encouraged

A form of diabetes experienced by some women during pregnancy. This resolves once the mother has delivered the baby in the majority of cases. This re -occurs with subsequent pregnancy and some patients develop Type 2 diabetes later in life.
A member of staff that supports the smooth running of diabetes clinics. Performs biomedical measurements, phlebotomy, an1d4
A device that delivers a continuous infusion of insulin. Patients are given extra insulin via the pump to prevent excessive blood glucose level rises after a meal
Multi-disciplinary team that includes Diabetologists, Diabetes Specialist Nurses and dieticians, and podiatrists
A complication of diabetes that can result in end stage renal failure, requiring renal replacement therapy i.e. dialysis
A complication of diabetes caused by damage to the nerves, resulting in a predisposition to ulceration and possible limb amputation
Nursing and dietetic diabetes care that supports women that have pre-existing diabetes to optimise their diabetes control prior to becoming pregnant. This reduces fetal risk including miscarriage.
A complication of diabetes that causes damage to the eyes and can lead to blindness
A form of diabetes in which the patient has no insulin production and thus requires insulin therapy to survive

A form of diabetes in which patients have insulin resistance and hyperglycemia (high blood glucose levels). Many of these patients have high blood pressure and cholesterol levels too. These patients are treated with tablets and / or insulin. To optimise blood glucose control and to avoid the long term complications of diabetes

Appendix 6
Summary of Diabetes Service Components
Diabetes Centre: Highly care specialist (MEHT)
Provides a hub for this consultant led service and the following aspects of the service are directed and led from this location. The majority of care is provided on a “one stop shop” model of care
Emergency and in-patient care
Complex care for patients with 2 or more diabetes related complications
Adolescent and Type 1 diabetes consultant led care
Pregnancy care in Type 1, Type 2 and gestational diabetes
Pre-conceptual care
Telephone service/email advice for admission avoidance and crisis intervention
Type 1, NICE compliant structured group education (BERTIE)
Insulin pump service
Consultant supported acute podiatry clinics
Baddow Village surgery (Tier 2): Specialist care (Provide)

The Tier 2 Community Diabetes service is the Provide arm of the integrated Mid Essex Diabetes service based at Baddow Village surgery. This is also managed by the Lead Diabetes Specialist Nurse for Diabetes based at the Diabetes Centre, as part of the Mid Essex Integrated service. It provides specialist diabetes care packages for people with Type 2 Diabetes Mellitus, and for those patients that require transient “step up” care, when the GP is unable to provide the appropriate level of service to meet a particular diabetes care need. The majority of care is provided on a “one stop shop” model of care
Services provide are:
Glycemic intensification (blood glucose level control)
Insulin conversion, (one to one and group)
Type 2, NICE compliant structured group education (X-pert )
One to one education
Telephone/ email support & advice for these groups
GP practices
Provide routine diabetes surveillance and care.
Diabetes retinal screening
Is provided by West Suffolk Community Services who are commissioned by the MID ESSEX clinical commissioning group (CCG).
